description: An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 102 C3 Illyrikon
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 102 D4 no. 10 (Hellas)

The late Roman province of Palaestina Secunda, established during the 4th century, comprised the region of northern Palestine, including Galilee and the southern Golan Plateau. Its capital was Skythopolis.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 102 F5 no. 57 (Aigyptos)
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 102 F6 no. 62 (Thebais Ano)
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 102 E5 no. 64 (Libye he Kato)
An ancient region corresponding to the Iberian peninsula and so roughly to the territories of the modern countries of Spain and Portugal.
The Italian peninsula extending northward to the Alps as recognized by the Romans.
The chief ancient city (civitas) of the Treveri. Modern Trier in Germany.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 1 K3 Syria
A village located near Jerusalem, at the Mount of Olives.
An ancient Roman city initially founded ca. 181/180 B.C., Aquileia is especially important in Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages.
Poetovio (Ptuj, Slovenia) was an ancient city in Pannonia that was the base-camp of Legio XIII Gemina.
The island of Great Britain is located to the northwest of continental Europe and is the ninth largest island in the world.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 2 E3 Germania
Dacia was a region inhabited by the Dacians or Getae. A Dacian kingdom existed from ca. the early first century BC until the Roman conquest under Trajan in AD 106.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 21 D6 Naissus
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 21 F7 Serdica
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 21 B5 Sirmium
An ancient city and Roman legionary base along the Danube, near modern Kostolac (Костолац, Caştelu) in Serbia.
A settlement which originally dates to the Chalcolithic period.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 3 D4 Arabia
Aethiopia is a term used in the Classical sources to refer both to Upper Egypt and the regions south of the Sahara desert. It is employed as early as the time of Homer.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 38 B1 Pentapolis
An ancient capital of Cyrenaica, Ptolemais was probably named after Ptolemy III Euergetes. The city was founded in either the seventh or sixth century BC.
A Celtic settlement and crossroads, later a Western Roman capital. Now modern Milan, Italy.
Originally a captial of the Libici, a tribe of Ligurians, Vercellae became an important Roman municipium.
Verona was an ancient settlement that became a Roman colonia in 89 BC and a municipium in 49 BC.
Arabicus Sinus/Erythr(ae)um/Rubrum Mare (The Red Sea) is an inlet of the Indian Ocean located between Africa and Asia.

Present-day Aksum in Ethiopia. The center of the Aksumite Kingdom, a maritime trading power that flourished from the first to the tenth centuries AD. The city was listed as UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1980.
Ariminum (Rimini) is a Roman colony founded on the Adriatic coast in 268 BC.

An ancient settlement of the Veneti, Patavium became a Roman municipium in 45 BC. It was the birthplace of several famous Romans including Titus Livius, Valerius Flaccus, Asconius Pedianus and Thrasea Paetus.
The capital of the Roman Republic and Empire.
An important ancient city of Campania with Villanovan and Etruscan origins.

Sicily is the largest island in the Mediterranean Sea and has been the site of human habitation since ca. 8,000 BC. In historical terms Sicily has seen important settlement activity connected to numerous culture groups - Punic, Carthaginian, Greek, Roman, Vandalic, Ostrogothic, Byzantine, Arabic, and Norman.
Central coastal plain between the Carmel and Joppe in modern Israel.
The second largest island in the Mediterranean Sea
Illyricum was a Roman province that existed from 167 BC until AD 10.
The region of ancient Macedonia in the Balkan peninsula. The boundaries of the region have shifted significantly over time, and remain controversial.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 50 C3 Therme
An ancient city founded as Philippi by the king of Macedon, Philip II of Macedon on the site of the Thasian colony of Krinides.

Thracia refers to a territory occupied by the Thraci (or Thracians), a human population of the northern Balkan Peninsula whose reach stretched from the north Aegean Sea to the Danube river. Parts of Thracia would eventually become incorporated into the Roman provinces of Moesia and Thracia.

Helikore/Nicaea (modern İznik, Turkey) was a Greek city of northwestern Anatolia. It was the site of the First and Second Councils of Nicaea and was the interim capital city of the Byzantine Empire between 1204 and 1261.
Nicomedia was founded in 712/11 BC as a Megarian colony named Astacus and was rebuilt by Nicomedes I of Bithynia in 264 BC. The city was an important administrative center of the Roman Empire.
Capital city of the Eastern Roman Empire, the Latin, and the Ottoman Empires founded by Constantine I in AD 330.
An ancient region that included northwest parts of modern Greece and the southern tip of modern Albania.
Euboea is the second largest Greek island by area and is separated from the Greek mainland by the Euripus Strait.
Elis was an ancient Greek city of the northeast Peloponnese that served as the capital of the district of the same name.
A major Greek city-state and the principal city of Attika. Modern Athens in Greece.
The island of Crete is the largest of the Greek islands and the fifth-largest island in the Mediterranean Sea.
Ephesus/Arsinoe(ia) was the most important ancient metropolis of Ionian Asia Minor.
An ancient city in Pisidia.
A region that stretched from Lake Tatta in the east to the upper Euphrates River and from the Black Sea southward to Cilicia.
Mazaka/Eusebeia/Caesarea was the chief town of Cappadocia, modern Kayseri.
Lycia was a region of southwestern Asia Minor.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 65 E4 Pamphylia
A region of southern Asia Minor.

A city founded ca. 300 BC by Seleucus I Nicator, a successor of Alexander the Great. Antioch was a great trading center and numbered as one of the four cities of the Syrian tetrapolis. Justinian I renamed the city 'Theoupolis' in the sixth century AD.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 68 A4 Antarados/Constantia
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 68 A3 Paltos
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 69 D3 Batanaia/Basanitis
An ancient Phoenician city, known by various names in antiquity, in what is now Lebanon.
A coastal mountain range in northern Israel.
The ancient city of Damascus, located in modern Syria, with some 125 monuments dating back to the Roman period. Inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1979.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 69 C3 Dan
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 69 C4 Gala(a)ditis
Galilaea was the northernmost region of Palaestina. Galilaea became a Seleucid territory after the conquests of Alexander the Great.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 69 B4 Kana?
A mountain range of northern Syria that is between the Mediterranean coastline and the Antilibanos mountains of the interior.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 69 B4 Nazareth
The ancient region of Samaria.
Samaria/Sebaste was an ancient city of Iudaea. In 30 B.C. it passed under the control of Herod the Great and was renamed Sebaste in honor of the emperor Augustus.

description: An ancient settlement in the Levant, attested Biblically and in ancient Egyptian documents and the Amarna letters. Scholars associate this settlement with the archaeological site of Tel Balata, which is located in the modern West Bank and has seen attention from archaeologists since the early 20th century.
Tiberias was founded by Herod Antipas ca. 20 BC.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 70 G2 Bethlehem

An ancient settlement of Judea that is mentioned in numerous ancient sources including the Gospel of Luke. Now situated within the modern Canada Park in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the site was known in modern times as Imwas and was populated until 1967.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 70 G2 Gabaon

An ancient site in the Jordan valley with occupation beginning ca. 11,000 years BP. The tell of Hierichous (Jericho) has more than 20 settlement horizons, ranging from Natufian Hunter-Gatherers to modern.
Idumaea or the kingdom of Edom was an historical region of the Levant located south of Iudaea and the Dead Sea.
The city of Jerusalem.

description: Ioppe (Jaffa) is an ancient port city in Iudaea.
Iordanes fl. (the Jordan river).

Iudaea was an historical region of the Levant located in the mountainous southern part of the Land of Palestine, roughly corresponding to the southern West Bank. The region's name derives from the biblical tribe of Judah and the associated Kingdom of Judah (ca. 934 until 586 BC).
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 70 G2 Modiin
A region at the southeastern coast of the Mediterranean Sea, encompassing the coastal plain between Phoenicia and Gaza. The region's name derives from the Hebrew Plšth, "the land of the Philistines."
Capital city of the Nabataeans located on the slope of Mount Hor.
Third largest island in the Mediterranean Sea.
The Siwa Oasis was, in antiquity, site of the oracular temple of Amun (Zeus Ammon).
An ancient place, cited: None
Marmarica was an ancient region of the North African coast between Cyrenaica and Aegyptus.
The westernmost town of ancient Egypt.
An ancient place, cited: None
The ancient port city in Egypt's Nile Delta, founded by Alexander the Great in 332/331 BCE.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 74 D3 Andronpolis
An ancient city of Lower Egypt located at present-day Tell Atrib to the northeast of Benha on the hill of Kom Sidi Yusuf.
Hermopolis Mikra was an ancient city of Egypt that served as  he capital of Lower Egypt's 7th Nome (A-ment).
A brackish lake of Lower Egypt (now Lake Mariout).
The Nile is a major river of northeastern Africa and is generally acknowledged as the longest river in the world, measuring some 6,650 km (4,130 miles) from source to mouth.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 74 E2 Pachnamounis
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 74 D2 Phragonis

Sais was an ancient Egyptian town located in the Western Nile Delta on the Canopic branch of the Nile river. It served as the provincial capital of Sap-Meh, the fifth nome of Lower Egypt, and became a capital during the Twenty-fourth Dynasty (ca. 732–720 BC) as well as during the Late Period. Herodotus claimed that Osiris was buried at Sais. Other Greek authors, including Plato, maintained a connection between Sais and the goddess Athena.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 74 C2 Schedia/Chaireon/Menelais?
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 74 F2 Tanis
empty
empty
An ancient city in the Heptanomis and the capital of Arsinoites nome. The ancient Egyptian name of the site was Shedyet and in Pharaonic times it was a major cult center for the god Sobek.

A province on the frontier of the Roman empire from the second century AD, Arabia Petraia comprised parts of the former kingdom of Nabataea, as well as southern Syria, the Sinai, and the northwestern part of the Arabian peninsula. Its capital was Petra.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 76 D4 Horeb Mons, Mon.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 76 D4 Syna M.
empty
A place from the TAVO Index

The region of modern North Africa to which the Romans referred as "Africa", effectively the majority of same with the exception of Egypt, later truncated to correspond to the Roman province of the same name.
Kharga: one of the large oases of Egypt’s Western Desert.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 80 B3 Latopolis

An ancient island located just above the first cataract of the Nile that was flooded by the construction of the Aswan High Dam. The island was home to a multi-period temple complex, which was moved to the nearby island of Agilkia and declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in the 1970s.
The ancient city of Swenett in Egypt, called Syene by the Greeks.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 80 B1 Thebais
A region of northeastern Anatolia consisting of the southeastern coast of the Black Sea and the surrounding inland region.
A mountainous strip of land in Jordan that was also the location of the kingdom of Moab, with its capital at Dibon.

Some texts of the late Roman Empire use the name "Arabia" for a region in Mesopotamia. The sources and scholarly speculation about origins of the name and the location of the reason are summarized by Dillemann. In BAtlas, T. Sinclair identifies this Arabia with "Tektek Dağ and district of Viranşehir."

This important Mesopotamian city flanks the eastern edge of the Tigris flood plain, opposite modern Mosul, of which it is now a suburb. From the third millennium B.C. onwards, Nineveh was the most important religious center of the goddess Ištar in the area that would become the Assyrian heartland. Starting in the Middle Assyrian period, the city came under the authority of the kings of Assyria, who often sponsored large-scale building activities there. However, it was not until 704 B.C. that Nineveh became the administrative capital of Assyria, when the Neo-Assyrian king Sennacherib moved the royal family and court there and transformed the city into a thriving imperial metropolis. Nineveh remained Assyria’s capital until 612 B.C., when it was captured and destroyed by a Babylonian-Median collation led by Nabopolassar and Cyaxares. The visible remains of the (7th-century) Assyrian city include the citadel mound Kuyunjik, the smaller mound of Nebi Yunus, and the twelve-kilometer-long city wall.

description: The ancient city of Babylon began as an Akkadian city-state founded by Amorites in 1894 B.C. The city was also the seat of the Neo-Babylonian Empire from 608 to 539 B.C.
An ancient Akkadian region in Mesopotamia.
An ancient Pre-Iranian civilization located in the west and southwest of modern-day Iran.
The longest river of Western Asia, the Euphrates flows from the Kara Su and the Murat Su to the confluence with the Tigris river.
An ancient city of the Elamite, Persian, and Parthian empires of Iran. Located at modern Shush, Susa was inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List in 2015.

description: Uruk was an ancient Sumerian (and later Babylonian) city located on the Euphrates river. At its height (ca. 2900 BC), Uruk's population may have topped 50,000 people and its walls enclosed an area of more than six square kilometers, making it the largest city in the world at that point in time.

The ancient kingdom(s) and region of Egypt as understood by the Egyptians themselves, their neighbors, and their successors. Individual administrative districts, provinces, nomes, and the like have separate place resources in Pleiades.
Territory west of the Euphrates and Armenia (Roman province) included in the province of Cappadocia by Vespasian.

The Roman province of Asia, located on the eastern coast of the Aegean Sea. The region was bequeathed to the Roman Republic by Attalus III of Pergamum in 133 BCE. It was divided into seven smaller provinces by Diocletian in the 4th century CE.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 100 N4 Cilicia
A province of the Roman Empire at the death of Trajan (117 CE).
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 100 P4 Mesopotamia
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 100 N4 no. 5 (Isauria)
Dardania was a Roman province located in the Central Balkans. First a region of Moesia, Dardania was made a part of the Diocese of Moesia in 293.

An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 101 M5 Libya Inferior
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 101 N6 Thebais
The post-Diocletianic province of Arabia according to the Verona List (ca. AD 303-324). It was assigned to the diocese of Oriens.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 101 L3 Moesiae

An ancient region covering a large part of southwestern Europe, roughly approximating the territory of modern France. It was bounded by the Atlantic ocean, the Pyrenees mountains, the Mediterranean, the Alps, and the river Rhine. Gallia was famously described by Caesar as the territory of the ancient Celts (Celtae), whom the Romans called Gauls (Galli in Latin), hence the common modern usage "Gaul" for the region.
